here in the US by 10%.
CHRISTI PAUL: Yeah.

China also announcing a rise
in spending by 7% there.

- It is an increase,
but that would

also be the smallest
increase China
has seen in about seven years.

CHRISTI PAUL: Until
last year, China's

military spending had gone
up at double-digit pace
ever since 2010.

For more on how US
military spending stacks up

against China,
we're joined by CNN

Military Analyst, Lieutenant
General Mark Hertling.

So good to see you, Lieutenant
General, being with us here.

We do want to start with
that military spending story

as we see the headline
this morning that China is

increasing their
spending by 7% and US
bumping up theirs by 10%.

I want to show you a look here
at worldwide military spending,
though.

US spending dwarfs the
rest of the world's

as we take a look at how
it all plays out there.
What do you make of the numbers?

MARK HERTLING: Well, a
couple things, Christi.

If I can go to China first,
I was in China in 1998

as part of a military delegation
from the National War College.
And it was fascinating for me.

Back in that year,
they were showing

what they were attempting to
do over the next three decades.

And they have gone
according to plan
all three of those decades.

I've been back several
times to Beijing since then,

and they have always
had about a 1.3%

of their GDP allocated
toward defense spending.

That has not changed, and
that's significantly less

than what the US has
in terms of spending.

The 7% increase this
year, as you just said,

is about what they've
had over the last couple

of years up and
down, but it's lower
than what they've had recently.

They are on a path to
become a regional power, not
a global power.

When you compare the
charts that show the United

States against the
next seven countries,

there's often people
that will say, "Hey.

We spend more than the next
seven, and five of those
are our allies."

That's true, but it's also
because we're the only

global power and
we have operations

being conducted
around the world with
a professional military force.

And when I mean professional--
or when I say "professional,"

I mean a group of
individuals who

join the service out
of their own free will
and are not drafted.

So all of those things
play a part in the amount
of spending we have--

having to do with pay for
personnel, global operations,

and an unbelievable
amount of acquisition

of the various advanced
level platforms.
CHRISTI PAUL: All right.

Let's talk about Russia
and David Petraeus,

what he had to say about
the motives of Russian
President Vladimir Putin.
Let's listen here together.

DAVID PETRAEUS: It's
very clear what Vladimir
Putin's objectives are.

In many cases, they
are unacceptable to us

and NATO and our allies and
partners around the world.

Having said that, there could
be some convergence of interests

when it comes to the defeat of
the Islamic State and al-Qaeda

and perhaps to stopping
the bloodshed in Syria
as an overall objective as well.

CHRISTI PAUL: Do
you agree with that,

and do you see any point,
General Hertling, where the US
and Russia could work together?

MARK HERTLING: There are
certainly always engaging

possibilities with other
countries, Christi,

and I think General
Petraeus is a good friend.
He had it just right.

We've got to be very
skeptibal-- skeptical,

excuse me, of Russia
in every regard because
of their strategic goals.

They have stated
outright that they

are willing to try
and disrupt the West,

disrupt NATO, and disrupt
the powers within the EU.

And they are doing that
in a variety of ways.

They have also become engaged
in the Middle East in some ways

and, in fact, have committed
war crimes in Syria.

So whereas it would be very
good to continue dialogue

with the Russians,
we've got to be

very skeptical and very careful
about how we do that dialogue.
CHRISTI PAUL: Being on guard.

And on that point, I want to
show something that you posted
on Facebook-- this picture.

And underneath it, you
quoted, "For the record,

I've met with Russians in
my house for dinner multiple
times, multiple places.

Don't know how many were
spies but always suspected

all of them were
reporting on me just
as I was reporting on them."

Help us understand that
dynamic and that atmosphere.
Are you constantly on guard?

Are there moments of
authenticity between you?
MARK HERTLING: There is.

There are always moments
where you can connect

with your counterpart,
which I did,

but you also have
to be very careful.

When I was commanding forces
in Europe and even before then,

I spent the last 10
years of my career

either in Europe,
Iraq, or Afghanistan
and dealt with the leaders--

not only the military but some
of the government leaders--

of 49 different countries
in those two areas.

And what I found
was, first of all,

you always have a note taker
in the room who can jot down

what's going on because you
don't want to engage in what's

called "engagement
fratricide" where you say

one thing and maybe one of your
coworkers or your colleagues

says something else
during the next meeting.

So you always want to
get your story straight,

and you always want to have
a record of what's going on.

You do have to engage
with these people.

But when you do that, you should
always be telling your boss
that you are engaging.

And I engaged--
CHRISTI PAUL: OK.

MARK HERTLING: --with Russians
not in my home in Wiesbaden

and in training centers
like Grafenwoehr,

but I went to Moscow and
several of their training sites
on several occasions.

And Russian
delegations often came

as part of our Council
of European Armies

where we had all of the
commanders of Europe together,

and we would always make
note of what was said,
who engaged with who.

And part of it is
just keeping record

and making sure you knew what
had to be done as well as--

CHRISTI PAUL: So the meeting
itself isn't the problem.

It's the reporting that it
happened is what's important.

MARK HERTLING: Well,
it's the record.
Yeah.

It's the record keeping
and the reporting

and informing your boss, whoever
your boss might happen to be.
CHRISTI PAUL: All right.

Lieutenant General Mark
Hertling, we always
appreciate having you on.
It's so good to see you again.
Thank you.

MARK HERTLING: Always
a pleasure, Christi.
Thank you.
